exempt.translation[0].definitions[0].def: not affected by something, or not having to do it or pay it
exempt.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The interest is exempt from income tax.
Children are exempt from the charges.
exempt.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to give someone permission not to do or pay something
exempt.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Charities are exempted from paying the tax.
a document that exempts the owner from liability in case of accidents
exempt.translation[1].definitions[0].not: In everyday British English, people usually say let somebody off (doing) something rather than exempt somebody from (doing) something:
Living abroad doesn’t necessarily let you off paying tax.
exempt.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to allow something that would normally be affected by a tax, law etc not to be affected
exempt.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Democrats would also tax the entire cost of private planes, while Republicans would exempt them.
The change in the tax law will exempt dividends from the recipient’s income taxes.
exempt.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to give permission to someone or to an organization not to do something that they would normally have to do
exempt.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: The new rules also exempt established companies from having to comply with all the new safety regulations.
exempt.translation[3].definitions[0].def: something that is exempt from a law, tax etc is not affected by that law etc when normally it might be
exempt.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Restaurant and delicatessen food will be exempt from the labeling requirements.
exempt.translation[3].definitions[1].def: someone who is exempt from something has special permission not to do it
exempt.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Students are not exempt from compulsory military service.
